These findings support the oxygen constraint hypothesis for body size evolution.

questions.question: Comparison of eye complexity across invertebrates: Planarian eyecup — ~100 photoreceptors, direction detection only; Nautilus pinhole eye — ~4 million photoreceptors, crude image formation; Jumping spider — ~600,000 photoreceptors in principal eyes, high-resolution image with UV detection; Mantis shrimp — ~10,000 ommatidia with 16 photoreceptor types, widest color spectrum of any animal. This diversity illustrates:
options: all invertebrates have identical visual systems
convergent evolution has produced diverse visual solutions optimized for different ecological niches and behavioral requirements
only vertebrates have evolved complex vision
eye complexity correlates only with body size
questions.explanation: The data showcases the remarkable diversity of invertebrate visual systems, each adapted to specific ecological demands. Planarian eyecups provide only directional light detection, sufficient for a photophobic burrower. Nautilus pinhole eyes (no lens) form crude images adequate for a slow-swimming, bottom-dwelling predator. Jumping spiders have extraordinary spatial resolution in their principal eyes (acute zone resolution rivaling primates), essential for visually guided predation and complex courtship displays. Mantis shrimp have the most complex color vision known, with 16 photoreceptor types spanning UV to far-red wavelengths, enabling detection of both linearly and circularly polarized light used in signaling. Each system represents an independent evolutionary solution to the challenge of extracting visual information from the environment, optimized for specific behavioral needs.

questions.question: The phenomenon of kin recognition in colonial marine invertebrates (e.g., Botryllus, a colonial tunicate) involves:
options: random aggregation with no specificity
histocompatibility-like systems where colonies can distinguish self from non-self, fusing with genetically similar colonies and rejecting dissimilar ones
all colonies fusing regardless of genetic relatedness
chemical signals that attract predators to non-kin colonies
questions.explanation: Colonial tunicates like Botryllus schlosseri have sophisticated allorecognition systems that determine whether adjacent colonies will fuse or reject each other. This is controlled by a single, highly polymorphic gene locus (FuHC—Fusion/Histocompatibility) analogous to the vertebrate MHC system. Colonies sharing at least one FuHC allele will fuse, forming chimeric colonies. Colonies with no shared alleles develop an inflammatory rejection response. This system prevents parasitic genotypes from invading colonies while allowing fusion between relatives (which share alleles). The Botryllus system is one of the most well-studied examples of invertebrate allorecognition and has provided insights into the evolution of immune systems, suggesting that self/non-self discrimination is an ancient capability predating the vertebrate adaptive immune system.

questions.question:
About invertebrate nervous systems:
(I) The octopus brain contains specialized lobes for learning and memory (vertical lobe system)
(II) Insect mushroom bodies function in olfactory learning and memory
(III) The giant axon of the squid was instrumental in understanding the ionic basis of nerve impulse conduction
(IV) All invertebrates lack any form of learning capability
Which are TRUE?
options: TTTF -- I, II, and III are true
TTFT -- I, II, and IV are true
TFTT -- I, III, and IV are true
TTTT -- All are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: The octopus vertical lobe system is critical for learning and memory, particularly one-trial learning. Lesion of the vertical lobe impairs visual discrimination learning. The octopus brain has approximately 500 million neurons organized into specialized lobes. Statement II is TRUE: Insect mushroom bodies (corpora pedunculata) are paired neuropils that process olfactory information and are critical for associative learning and memory. Their size correlates with behavioral complexity—social hymenoptera have enlarged mushroom bodies. Statement III is TRUE: The giant axon of the squid Loligo (up to 1 mm diameter, 100x larger than typical axons) was used by Hodgkin and Huxley in their Nobel Prize-winning work on action potential ionic mechanisms. Statement IV is FALSE: Invertebrates from C. elegans to octopuses demonstrate various forms of learning including habituation, sensitization, classical conditioning, and spatial learning.

questions.question: To determine whether the symbiotic bacteria in the light organ of the bobtail squid (Euprymna scolopes) are selected for by the host or acquired randomly from the environment, a researcher should:
options: observe squid swimming in the ocean

raise squid from eggs in water containing a mixture of bacterial species including Vibrio fischeri, then analyze which species colonize the light organ using molecular identification methods, with controls including sterile-water-raised squid and squid exposed to water without V. fischeri
measure the intensity of bioluminescence at different depths
compare the genome size of the squid with other cephalopods
questions.explanation: The Euprymna-Vibrio symbiosis is one of the best-studied animal-microbe associations. To test host selectivity: (1) Raise squid from eggs in filtered seawater (squid hatch aposymbiotic—without bacteria). (2) Expose hatchlings to seawater containing known mixtures of bacterial species including V. fischeri and closely related non-symbiotic Vibrio species. (3) After colonization, use 16S rRNA sequencing and species-specific probes to determine which bacteria successfully colonized the light organ. (4) Controls: sterile-water squid (no colonization), and water lacking V. fischeri (test whether other species can substitute). Research using this approach has shown that the squid has sophisticated selection mechanisms: the light organ produces mucus that selectively enriches V. fischeri, epithelial cells produce antimicrobial peptides that eliminate most bacteria, and the internal environment selectively supports V. fischeri growth.

questions.question: The madreporite of a sea star connects the water vascular system to the external environment. If the madreporite were experimentally blocked, which function would be MOST immediately impaired?
options: Gamete release during spawning
Hydraulic pressure regulation in tube feet
Calcium carbonate deposition in ossicles
Diffusion of respiratory gases across papulae
questions.explanation: The madreporite is a sieve plate that allows seawater to enter the water vascular system, which operates hydraulically. Blocking it would immediately impair the hydraulic pressure needed for tube foot extension and locomotion. The water vascular system is critical for movement, attachment, and feeding in asteroids. While echinoderms do use papulae for respiration, this occurs via direct diffusion through the body wall and is independent of the water vascular system. Gamete release and skeletal deposition are also not directly dependent on madreporite function.

questions.question: The phylogenetic position of Ctenophora (comb jellies) has been debated regarding whether they or Porifera represent the sister group to all other animals. Which molecular evidence would MOST strongly support Ctenophora as the earliest-diverging animal lineage?
options: Ctenophores possess hox genes absent in sponges
Ctenophore mitochondrial genome organization resembles that of choanoflagellates
Ctenophores lack many neural gene families found in all other animals including sponges
Ctenophore collagen genes are more similar to fungal homologs than to sponge collagen
questions.explanation: The 'Ctenophora-sister' hypothesis, which places comb jellies rather than sponges as the earliest-diverging animal lineage, is supported by genomic analyses showing that ctenophores lack many gene families associated with neural signaling that are present in sponges and all other animals. This suggests either independent evolution of nervous systems in ctenophores or loss in sponges. The absence of these conserved neural gene families in ctenophores, combined with phylogenomic tree analyses, provides the strongest molecular support for their basal position. Mitochondrial genome comparisons and collagen gene analyses have not been the primary evidence driving this hypothesis.

questions.question: Researchers measured the regeneration rate of planarian flatworms after transverse amputation at different body positions. Anterior fragments regenerated a new tail in 5 days, while posterior fragments required 8 days to regenerate a new head. When middle fragments were cut, anterior-facing wounds regenerated heads and posterior-facing wounds regenerated tails simultaneously. Which mechanism BEST explains the polarity of regeneration?
options: Differential distribution of neoblast stem cells along the anterior-posterior axis
A morphogen gradient (e.g., Wnt signaling) that specifies positional identity along the body axis
Selective apoptosis of cells that do not match the required tissue type at each wound
Mechanical tension differences between anterior and posterior wound surfaces
questions.explanation: Planarian regeneration polarity is primarily controlled by Wnt signaling gradients along the anterior-posterior axis. High Wnt/beta-catenin activity at the posterior end specifies tail identity, while low Wnt activity (maintained by Wnt inhibitors like notum) at the anterior end specifies head identity. When a middle fragment is cut, the anterior-facing wound has low Wnt and regenerates a head, while the posterior-facing wound has high Wnt and regenerates a tail. While neoblasts are essential for regeneration as pluripotent stem cells, they are distributed throughout the body and do not themselves determine polarity. The morphogen gradient provides positional information that directs neoblast differentiation.

questions.question: Tardigrades (water bears) can survive extreme desiccation by entering a state called cryptobiosis. During this tun state, which molecular adaptation is MOST critical for protecting cellular structures?
options: Upregulation of aquaporins to maintain minimal water content
Synthesis of antifreeze glycoproteins that stabilize membrane lipids
Activation of heat-shock protein 70 to prevent all protein denaturation
Production of trehalose and intrinsically disordered proteins that vitrify the cytoplasm
questions.explanation: During cryptobiosis, tardigrades produce large amounts of trehalose (a non-reducing disaccharide) and tardigrade-specific intrinsically disordered proteins (TDPs) that form a biological glass (vitrification) as water is lost. This glassy matrix immobilizes cellular components and prevents damage from desiccation. The vitrified cytoplasm maintains structural integrity without liquid water. While heat-shock proteins contribute to stress tolerance, the vitrification by trehalose and TDPs is the most critical adaptation specific to the tun state. Aquaporins actually facilitate water loss during tun formation rather than retaining water, and antifreeze glycoproteins are primarily associated with freeze tolerance in other organisms.
